comments.commentBody:
Is it not useful to critique a very influential blogger wasting his time pointing out the obvious?

One could make the argument in defense of Krugman that he's using his popular blog to get the message out, "Beware of phony GOPopulists." He's probably concerned VSP will start buying into the notion of GOPopulism.

He's also saying Jindal's tax proposals are more blatant in helping the rich because of the immediate projected impact on the middle class and poor.

But I list 12 areas that have more influence on the economy, and people's well being, than the future possible sources of state revenue in Louisiana (or price of eggs in China). Some areas overlap, some are interconnected, all contribute to an overriding problem of inequality. The kicker about the NLRB means I think it's an important symbol of Obama's and the Democrat's weakness in a very important area.

Also, the clear implication of my comment is that criticizing Republicans shouldn't take up more of an economic debate than promoting policies to End This Depression Now!

Again, even just refocusing attention on the areas listed that are in need of economic analysis and updated proposals for a Democratic plan is helpful and useful.

What about the retired? At least those currently earning income can pay lower income taxes to offset the higher sales tax burden. Retirees, however, already paid high rates on their incomes when they worked, and now when they are spending their low-interest-earning savings to buy necessities, whatever is left of their lifetime earnings will be taxed again. Retirees generally don't earn enough to make lower income taxes worth much to them.

I can't imagine the generally regressive nature of this proposed change would lead to adoption, but I've seen enough "Fair Tax" bumper stickers on beat-up cars to erode my faith in the electorate.
So any change like this needs to exempt tax-paid savings as of the effective date from the increase in sales tax rate with a credit.

Janet
Could not have said it better.

It amazes me how many WOMEN do not really get the true issue here. It worries me that the younger generation of women in the US are not out in droves to preserve the right to control their own bodies. It is actually frightening.

Societies do the most outrageous things in the name of hypocritical religious righteousness and use the state to enforce this dogma. In a country as supposedly advanced as we are is even more scary.

I am in Thailand and priests can not be touched or touch a woman. Female genital mutilation is being debated in emerging nations. We never learn that women are truly a marginalized group and we buy into the dogma. We made progress in the US and other developing nations but we are losing ground on a daily basis.

1) Under the guise of exercising "control over your own body", you are not permitted to raise your fist and beat your invalid mother-in-law to death, regardless of how inconvenient her continued life may be to you. She has legal rights. Similarly, if the legal rights of a fetus as a human being are recognized, you are not permitted to take his/her life regardless of how inconvenient his/her continued life may be to you.

2) Whether a 3-month old fetus is a human life with the rights of a new-born CAN be decided objectively and is NOT purely a matter of religious belief. It only takes a little political courage. Scientifically, it makes sense to say that a human being exists from the time a unique human genome is created, i.e. at conception. This makes more scientific sense than any talk of trimesters, viability, or independence. An adult human being is still a human when he can no longer feed and clothe himself or make independent decisions. Why should similar limitations deprive a fetus of humanity, when it is only a matter of time and natural growth before he/she will be free of them?

The pro-abortion camp should concentrate on finding justifications, if any, for withholding legal protection from fetuses (justifiable homicide). To continue to maintain that they are not human beings merely prolongs an unsolvable battle.

It is useless to debate the issue of abortion given that we can not agree on the nature of the fetus. Whether or not a 3-month old fetus is a human life with the rights of a new born can not be decided objectively. It is a matter of religious belief.

We should all agree that every pregnancy should be wanted. Birth control needs to be easily available to all women so that abortions are extremely rare. Those in the pro-life movement reveal their true agenda is not preserving the life of the fetus but controlling the sexual activity of young women when they also seek to restrict access to birth control.

So. Mr. Douthat, you will understand why some of us don't believe there is such a being as an anti-abortion feminist. A true feminist does not seek to control the lives of other women, especially through the power of the state. We have had enough of laws and cultural practices that have dictated what we can and cannot do with our own bodies.

mr. beck,
terrific blog...intelligent and informative. your respondents are basketball smart. i wish sports radio was at this level.
i, too, miss what j. lin brought to the knicks. nothing like it before, and not likely to be again.
it was sadly funny to read and hear the rationalizations for why he wasn't given a real trial by pro basketball before the knicks used him in desperation when they had no other options.
the stars must have been in perfect alignment for him to blow by all that defense, and score and pass so brilliantly. if d'antoni hadn't grievously over-extended his playing time, and the other teams hadn't gone out of their way to injure him, he'd still be playing at a very high level. so what if he can't go to his left that well, he went to his right brilliantly. i truly hope he's made a full recovery from knee surgery. few do.

Bill Gates has an excellent piece in the January 25 Wall Street Journal on the importance of measurement to solve big problems. ("My Plan to Fix The World's Biggest Problems" at http://online.wsj.com/article/SB1000142412788732353980457826178064828577...
The lede reads as follows: "From the fight against polio to fixing education, what's missing is often good measurement and a commitment to follow the data. We can do better. We have the tools at hand."
His point applies equally well to problems of gun violence.
Well stated on learning from others. The height of our arrogance is the idea of "American exceptionalism," a term that I would truly like to see eliminated from both writing and thinking.

"We Americans are not good at learning from others."

Absolutely correct! Health care is another good example.

Yes, I agree that we need more research on gun violence, but we certainly know enough to move ahead with gun control legislation.  And I hope that we will give more airing to comparison to other countries.  I heard an interview today with Charles Wheelan, author of Naked Statistics.  He stated that to have more valuable statistics on gun violence we would need to  have two Americas, one with guns and one without to get useful data characteristic of a blind study.  Of course that is impossible and silly to contemplate.  We have in abundance the experience of other countries.  We Americans are not good at learning from others.  In this matter especially we need to stop being so arrogant.

You got it backwards. Any attempt by the government to gather data on who owns or uses guns is a step toward confiscation. And that is the threat of tyranny that the 2nd Amendment is designed to prevent. It is the unknown presence of weapons among the citizenry that keeps the government in check. The threat of socialism and tyranny is real and increasing every day, especially with someone like Obama issuing executive orders.
Is the collection of data by the DMV a step toward confiscating cars and motorcycles?

Prohibiting scientific analysis of gun violence reminds me of prohibiting critical thinking skills from being taught in Texas schools or Taliban throwing acid in the face of young female students in Afghanistan.

Enforcing ignorance is a tool of primary importance to fascist movements.
Serena has smeared herself with abominable behavior over the years. Her meltdown in Melbourne is just the latest in a continuing--and disgusting to watch--series.
go sloane...and keep going...until you're gone.
Rose, I know you hate Fed, but talk to us about any of these pretenders eclipsing Fed when any of them approach 18 Grand Slams. Otherwise, keep your churlish--and foolish--comments to yourself.
Latex must be fairly uncomfortable, not at all breathable. At first, I had my dominatrix in only a LATEX (cat) MASK.

hi Chris,  you ask a good question, but the answer is a bit different.  The latent heat of melting ice is still small relative to the enormous heat capacity of the oceans.  The ARGO float program is getting better data on the change in heat content of the oceans. There are a bunch of ARGO buoys that sample the ocean at different depths and send the data back to NOAA.  The program is still relatively new. The expected T changes in the ocean are quite small give its large heat capacity, so long observing times are clearly better than a few years.  Both the upper ocean (often take for this purpose to be above 700 m) and the deeper ocean (mean depth 3800 m) show signs of warming but as time goes on we will have better data.  So the "missing hear" could easily be n the oceans.  See for example von Schuckmann Jour Geophys Res 09 and both Meehl 2011  Nat Clim Change and Loeb Nat Geosci 2012 for useful studies.  They suggest continued heat uptake by the oceans and would not easily be reconciled with the new Norwegian study. Heating the ocean causes thermal expansion and sea level rise, so SL data should constrain the problem.  The difficulty is sorting out how much SL change is from ice melt and how much from expansion (steric) at the level of uncertainty necessary.  The difficulty of recognizing and quantifying heat  changes in the oceans has long been known, but there isn't an easy way around the largest heat sink on the planetary surface.
andrew you should really move these comments by Annan to an update of the article rather than have them buried here in the comments. They strike me as important.
MM, only if you assume - as you obviously do - that it's about "the cause".  You missed the boat.

"A value (slightly) under 2 is certainly looking a whole lot more plausible than anything above 4.5."

What on earth does this mean? If 2 is as plausible as 4.5, our best guess would then be (2+4.5)/2 = 3.25 -- smack in the middle of consensus, and well above 2. If "slightly" under two is more plausible than 4.5, then our expectation value is now a bit lower than 3.5, but only "slightly". So 3, say. Again, smack in the middle of consensus and well over 2.

The climate scientist James Annan sent these thoughts by email:

Well, the press release is a bit strange, because it sounds like it is talking about the Aldrin et al paper which was published some time ago, to no great fanfare. I don't know if they have a further update to that.

Anyway, there have now been several recent papers showing much the same - numerous factors including: the increase in positive forcing (CO2 and the recent work on black carbon), decrease in estimated negative forcing (aerosols), combined with the stubborn refusal of the planet to warm as had been predicted over the last decade, all makes a high climate sensitivity increasingly untenable. A value (slightly) under 2 is certainly looking a whole lot more plausible than anything above 4.5.

James

[His blog: http://julesandjames.blogspot.com/ ]
oooh  -- 63-across  just sank in!  OK, four plusses and a minus!  :)

After I filled the grid completely I circled the fills corresponding to the dashed clues and stared at the grid for a while, and then the lightbulb went on. Wow. The thing that did it for me was 58D -- you see the top part (DELI) and the bottom part (ESSEN) and then the thing in the middle hits you. The others fell very quickly.

My biggest problem afterwards was figuring out how to make a comment in the blog without introducing spoilers, but Deb took care of that. I guess you could call this a crosscat puzzle ....

Interesting -- this one was a moderately difficult puzzle also, but not obnoxious. I've noticed hard puzzles are either nice or nasty, and I admire the constructors of the nice ones greatly. Jeff Chen falls in that category. :)
I was wrong: Pete Sampras was another who was both supremely talented and someone who never resorted to gamesmanship, at least as far as I can recall.
I'm with Deb on this one. Plus TMI.

What MOL said. I might agree with Howie too, but I don't understand what he said.

Thanks, fellow cat lover, for a nice puzzle and for coming to visit us.

DLD, Allow me to 'splain what I was talkin in my very early comment this morning...FB stands for feline behind! :-)

Howie

Seeing as Jill and I have three cats between us, it was impossible for me not to create this puzzle.

Now if I could just figure out how to keep Jill's cat from attempting to rub her butt hole on me.

Happy Halloween!
Jeff
jeffchen1972@gmail.com

An element's valence is a measure of how many electrons it can donate or accept in forming a bond. The sodium and chlorine atoms in NaCl have a valence of one. Most atoms can have several valences. In ferrous chloride, FeCl2, the iron atom has a valence of 2; in ferric chloride, FeCl3, it's 3.

Valence was an early clue to the wonders of the periodic table's organization.

And yes, this is way fewer words than would be needed to define valence properly.

Spoke too soon in my earlier comment: I had CROP PLANES
for 72D -- those were the real barnstormers! -- and thought CESO was a variation on "queso" for cheese. Ah, what lengths the mind goes ...

Note that the dates of declines she graphs began in the Reagan Era.  He was front man for the Great Swindle of the middle class,

Elisabeth Warren has done some excellent research on this; middle class families pay more for a mortgage on a home in a good school district, competing with each other for a scarce resource. In addition, they pay more for what they absolutely have to have for the second income: daycare and a second car, plus they pay more for their health insurance.

Americans spend less on everything discretionary than they did a generation ago. She draws this conclusion from US government data collected regularly for more than a century.

Here is a pre-Great Recession lecture on the coming collapse of the middle class by then professor, now Senator Warren.

http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=akVL7QY0S8A
@Deadline:  Rijkstra was kvetching there should have been a fifth "plus" in the center, but instead there's a "minus".  Nevertheless the theme symmetry is nicely preserved.

Also note the print ad featuring the supporting cast of Silver Linings beaming at one another while looking towards the movie's two stars who are placed at the center of the "ad" and looking straight out at the reader.  Harvey did the same "curtain call" thing last year with his campaign for The Artist so it's getting old hat (as well as corny).  Even so, why mess with success?

Thanks for these links.
As a social policy researcher and then a journalist in pre-Internet days I found it easier to find things in print than today electronically.
Writing on taxes, I remember the thrill of revelation on first looking into OECD's Revenue Statistics of member nations to which I was initiated by the director of the UBC school of social work.
I know it's heresy, but I found sifting through the government documents section of a good library far more efficient than Googling subjects. Despite the convenience of hyperlinks, I prefer print.
As a retiree pursuing solo anti-poverty advocacy I don't have the same access to experts previously enjoyed, so I'm one older man whose heart brightens when finding a reading list for current work on comparative taxes, income distributions and income security.
We really do need another Michael Harrington to wake up America by showing The Other America.
L -- stick with Deb -- you 'll get an education.
Martin?  These constructors DO NOT need helpful suggestions about being more diabolical and nasty.,

Interesting that Deb's blog and some comments both refer to the second-part clues as 'dashes'...When I saw them, I mentally saw 'hyphens', and that directed me to look back at the previous fill; so that was helpful in catching on early.

What's in a name, eh?

Give it up, Leapy. I've been a stickler about differentiating between dashes and hyphens in speech and writing, and I'm usually all alone.

I didn't take them as anything, really, except a signal to look around and see what was going on. It worked.

The most impressive thing about this theme is that each cat phrase consists of three real words (including cat).  It might have been fun to clue the final parts of the phrases as entries rather than use the dashes.  That, and a subtler title, would have been diabolical.  Those theme entries whose first parts share the clue with the full entry (DELI, DELICATESSEN) would compound the trick.  If only ALL the theme entries could be contrived to have such ambiguous first-component clues, this could have been the nastiest ever.
Actually, CATERWAUL comes close ...
